text: Require multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all administrative and privileged accounts in alignment with the Access Control Policy.
Users must keep passwords secure and must not share accounts as required in the Acceptable Use Policy.
Authentication mechanisms, including multi-factor authentication if applicable, must be followed according to the Acceptable Use Policy.
Perform regular vulnerability scans and remediate findings in accordance with the Information Security Policy.
Ensure all security patches are applied within defined timelines per the Information Security Policy.
Maintain an incident reporting process for all staff, aligned with the Incident Response Policy, including escalation procedures.
Conduct regular incident response exercises to validate the effectiveness of the Incident Response Policy.
Users must be informed of security requirements and responsibilities for handling information as outlined in the Acceptable Use Policy.
Track and document employee participation in security training programs to ensure compliance with the Information Security Policy.
Sensitive information such as NCIC data must be encrypted and protected from unauthorized access as stated in the Acceptable Use Policy.
Limit administrative privileges to authorized personnel and review them regularly as defined in the Access Control Policy.
Ensure the use of separate accounts for administrative and non-administrative tasks as outlined in the Access Control Policy.
Information security must be maintained during network disruptions or security incidents, in alignment with the Acceptable Use Policy.
Information must be labeled and classified (Confidential, Internal, Public) according to the organization's Information Classification Policy referenced in the Acceptable Use Policy.
